III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (4) Rooms, exterior walls, doors, skylights, and windows shall be
Description weather tight and watertight and shall be kept in sound condition
and in good repair.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A is able to pop the lock on his door and exit their room.
Youth A has escalated behaviors at times and makes others feel
unsafe.
Investigation This complaint was transferred to DCWL and assigned on
07/31/2024.
Complainant was anonymous.
Supervisor was interviewed at the facility on 07/31/2024.
Supervisor denied any incidents involving Youth A popping the
lock of his bedroom and getting out of his room. He reported there
was an incident yesterday involving Youth A getting upset about
not wanting his bed sheets washed. Youth A broke the carbon
monoxide detector, grievance box, and the classroom door. He
said the Therapist was on the pod and was able to get Youth A to
de-escalate. he said since this incident, Youth A has been placed
on a pod by himself. Youth B and Youth C were on the Pod with
Youth A during this incident but were moved to another pod due to
Youth A’s aggressive behavior.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 07/31/2024. Youth A
was interviewed on the Pod. Youth A is 15 years old and has been
at the facility for 3 months. He denied he has popped the lock on
his bedroom door. Youth A reported he had an episode on
07/30/2024 but does not recall what happened. Youth A reported
all his needs are being met, staff are always supervising, and he
feels safe.
Youth B and Youth C refused to be interviewed on 07/31/2024.
Juvenile Justice Worker (JJ Worker) was interviewed via
telephone on 07/31/2024. JJW reported she is not aware of Youth
A having blackouts, but this maybe his way of not telling the truth.
Youth A is currently facing three new charges for assaulting staff.
2

She is not aware of any incidents where Youth A has popped the
lock or gotten out of his room. JJ Worker said Youth A is a very
difficult and challenging youth and the facility is doing the best
they can with Youth A. JJ worker said, “I am praying for the
facility.”
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 08/02/2024.
Therapist reported she has been working with Youth A for three
months. She is not aware of any incidents involving Youth A being
able to pop the lock on his door. She reported there was an
incident on 07/30/2024 and she was on the Pod with Youth A.
Youth A did not want his bedding washed and became escalated.
She was able to get Youth A back to baseline. Youth A was not
restrained. Youth A is currently placed on a Pod by himself. She
said Youth A has threatened and assaulted staff in the past. She
is working with Youth A and has seen him making progress in
reference to his aggressive behavior.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 09/05/2024. Staff 1 and
denied witnessing Youth A popping the locks on his bedroom
doors. Staff 1 recalled hearing that Youth A was trying to jam the
lock on this bedroom door, but he has not witnessed Youth A
popping the lock on his bedroom door. Staff 1 could not recall who
told him or when this occurred.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on 09/05/2024. Staff 2 has
been working at the facility for 2 months. Staff 2 is familiar with
Youth A, but she is not aware of any incident involving Youth A or
any other youths popping the locks on their rooms. Staff 2
reported Youth A does try to bully and threaten staff. Staff 2 was
working on the Pod with Youth A on 07/30/2024 and recalls Youth
A refused to give a marker to the supervisor and became very
escalated. She said the Therapist was on the pod and was able to
verbally de-escalate Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 09/05/2024. Youth B is
currently on the same pod with Youth A. Youth B denied Youth A
or any other Youth has popped the locks on the bedroom doors.
Youth B reported there is always a staff member supervising, and
he feels safe. Youth B did not express any concerns regarding the
facility.
Youth C again refused to be interviewed at the facility on
09/05/2024.
3

Administrator was interviewed at the facility on 09/05/2024.
Administrator reported she is not aware of any incidents involving
Youth A being able to pop the lock on his bedroom door and get
out. She reported the facility has a lock smith that does quarterly
checks on all the locks at the facility. She said the locksmith was
at the facility on 08/12/2024 and checked all the locks.
Administrator reported they have had to move Youth A due to his
aggressive behavior. She said they currently only have male staff
working with Youth A due to his aggressive behavior.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report dated 07/30/2024, written by Supervisor.
Youth A was upset about his bedding needing to be
removed to be washed. Youth A took a black marker and
wrote on the walls, broke the carbon monoxide detector
and the grievance box, and used the table to break the
classroom door. Supervisor and Therapist were able to
verbally de-escalate Youth A without further incidence. No
incident reports were found indicating Youth A popped the
lock of his room and escaped.
• Youth supervision policy states proper supervision of youth
is necessary to ensure youth and staff safety and to
prevent escape. Staff are always responsible for the
supervision and ongoing safety and security of youth.
Youth may never be left unattended or unsupervised by
staff. Staff shall maintain within continuous “line-of-sight
supervision” when youth are outside of their rooms. Staff
shall monitor youth closely to assess the need for de-
escalation and/or the agency’s therapeutic crisis
intervention model.
• Aspen Door Supply inspection completed on 08/12/2024-
Quarterly Walk through.
Pod 2, 4, 5, and 6 - no issues.
Pod 1 room 4 - hinge screws needed to be tightened, room
10 missing screw on lock, which was fixed.
Pod 3 - hinge screw needed to be tightened.
Pod 7 - room 6-tighten screw on lock.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed, there is insufficient
evidence to support the allegations that Youth A is able to pop the
lock on his bedroom door.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: An anonymous complaint alleged that a youth at the Calumet Center could pop his bedroom lock and exit, creating safety concerns. The state investigation involved multiple interviews and document reviews, finding no evidence to support the lock-popping claim, though it confirmed the youth had recent aggressive incidents resulting in property damage. Based on witness statements, facility policies, and a recent locksmith inspection showing minor maintenance, the investigator concluded the violation was not established, effectively clearing the facility of the specific allegation.
